Welcome to the official documentation for the COVID-19 and MPOX Data API. This API provides comprehensive access to epidemic data for research, analysis, and visualization purposes.
Public & Protected Endpoints: Access basic data without authentication or use protected endpoints for complete access
Comprehensive Data: Access COVID-19 and MPOX statistics from countries around the world
RESTful Design: Simple, intuitive API design with consistent patterns
JSON Responses: All data is returned in clean, structured JSON format
TypeScript Support: Built with TypeScript for type safety and better development experience

Returns summary statistics for both COVID and MPOX.
This endpoint provides a high-level overview of the global situation for both diseases. It's particularly useful for dashboards and summary visualizations.
The statistics endpoint aggregates data from the latest available date for all countries. This means:
The totals represent the sum of all country data from the most recent date in the database
Some countries may have more recent data than others
The numbers reflect the state of the database, not necessarily real-time global figures
For the most accurate country-level statistics, use the specific COVID and MPOX endpoints.

The MPOX dataset differs from the COVID dataset in several important ways:
Coverage: MPOX data is available for fewer countries compared to COVID data
Fields: MPOX data does not include recovery statistics
Granularity: MPOX data may be reported with less frequency than COVID data
When integrating MPOX data into your applications, be aware of these differences and ensure your code handles them appropriately.

The COVID and MPOX Data API uses a simple bearer token authentication system to protect certain endpoints. This guide explains how to authenticate with the API.
The API uses a static bearer token for authentication. When making requests to protected endpoints, you must include this token in the Authorization header.
Add the following header to your HTTP requests:
Replace your-api-token with the actual API token provided to you.
If authentication fails, you will receive a 401 Unauthorized response:
Contact the API administrator to obtain an API token. Each client or application should use its own unique token.
Don't include the token directly in client-side code
Use environment variables to store the token
Use HTTPS to prevent token interception
For Node.js applications, store your token in an environment variable:
Remember that only certain endpoints require authentication. Public endpoints can be accessed without a token.
All other endpoints require authentication, including all data modification endpoints (POST, PUT, DELETE) and some data retrieval endpoints (GET).
Now that you understand authentication, you can explore the API Reference to learn about specific endpoints.
